title: How to Make a Beaded Wind Chime

steps.title: Drill some holes into a piece of driftwood.
steps.content: Drill some holes into a piece of driftwood. [1] X Research source Use an electric drill and a small drill bit to do this. You can drill as many or as few holes as you'd like, but try to space them evenly. Make sure that you are drilling all the way through the wood. Can't find any driftwood? Use a branch or a dowel instead.

steps.title: Decide how long you want your chimes to be, then cut your string twice as long.
steps.content: Decide how long you want your chimes to be, then cut your string twice as long. [2] X Research source The best type of string to use would be nylon beading thread, fishing line, or beading wire. You will need one length of string for each hole that you made. The strings don't all have to be the same length.

steps.title: Tie a mini bell to the end of each string.
steps.content: Tie a mini bell to the end of each string. Use a tight, double knot, and don't trim off the tail end. [3] X Research source For a stronger hold, slip a crimp bead over the knot, and pinch it shut with a pair of pliers. [4] X Research source Don't have bells? Use anything else that will make noise when clinked together. Metal charms, shells, and keys would all work great!

steps.title: Slip glass beads onto the string.
steps.content: Slip glass beads onto the string. Make sure to push the first couple of beads through both strands of string so that the tail end from the knot doesn't stick out. You can string the beads randomly or use a pattern. Leave a few inches/centimeters at the other end of the string empty. Consider adding some metal and wood beads for an interesting effect. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the string through the holes in the driftwood.
steps.content: Pull the string through the holes in the driftwood. At this point, take a look at the chime, and decide whether or not you are happy with the length. If something is too long, pull a few beads off. You can make your wind chime look more interesting by varying the lengths.

steps.title: Thread a large bead onto the string and tie the string around the bead in a tight knot.
steps.content: Thread a large bead onto the string and tie the string around the bead in a tight knot. Make sure that the bead is large enough so that it doesn't slip through the hole in the wood. [6] X Research source The bead will help keep the string in place.

steps.title: Pull the string back down the hole.
steps.content: Pull the string back down the hole. Thread it back through the last couple of beads on your chime, then cut off the excess. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Cut some twine, and wrap both ends around your chime to make the hanger.
steps.content: Cut some twine, and wrap both ends around your chime to make the hanger. Tie the ends of the twine to itself with a knot to secure it. [8] X Research source If you'd like something fancier, drill a hole into each end of the driftwood, then insert a small hook. Attach the hooks to a delicate chain.

steps.title: Take apart an embroidery hoop.
steps.content: Take apart an embroidery hoop. Discard the outer part with the metal ring, and keep the smooth, inner part. You can use a plastic embroidery hoop or a wooden one. If you use a wooden embroidery hoop, you can paint it any color you wish.

steps.title: Paint the embroidery hoop, if desired, and let it dry.
steps.content: Paint the embroidery hoop, if desired, and let it dry. You can leave wooden embroidery hoops plain for a rustic effect, or you can paint them with acrylic paint. Painting plastic hoops is not recommended because the paint is more likely to chip off. If you will be using this wind chime outside, spray the hoop with a clear, acrylic sealer once the paint has dried.

steps.title: Cut some string twice as long as you want your chimes to be.
steps.content: Cut some string twice as long as you want your chimes to be. You can have as many or as few chimes as you want. They can all be the same length, or they can be different lengths. The best type of string to use for this would be nylon beading thread or fishing line.

steps.title: Tie a metal charm to the end of each string.
steps.content: Tie a metal charm to the end of each string. You can use small bells, metal findings, keys, or anything that will make a sound when clinked together. Some people like to use vintage spoons!

steps.title: Slip assorted beads onto the string.
steps.content: Slip assorted beads onto the string. Be sure to slip the first couple of beads through both the string and the tail end. This will keep everything looking neat, and prevent the tail end of the knot from sticking out. Leave a few inches/centimeters at the end of each string empty.

steps.title: Tie the strings to the embroidery hoop.
steps.content: Tie the strings to the embroidery hoop. Wrap the string around the hoop a few times tightly, so that the last bead bumps up against the bottom edge. Tie the tail end to the string in a tight, double knot, then feed it back down through the beads.

steps.title: Cut 4 equal-length pieces of string.
steps.content: Cut 4 equal-length pieces of string. You will be using this to hang your wind chime, so choose something sturdy. Fishing line or twine would work well, but ordinary thread or yarn won't.

steps.title: Tie the end of each string to the embroidery hoop.
steps.content: Tie the end of each string to the embroidery hoop. Wrap the string around the hoop a few times, then tie it to itself. While the beaded strings are hanging down, these strings should be hanging up. Try to space these as evenly as you can.

steps.title: Tie the ends of the strings together, then slip them over a hook.
steps.content: Tie the ends of the strings together, then slip them over a hook. Gather the loose ends of your strings together, and check that the tension is even. Tie them together into a single knot, then slip them over a hook. Use the hook to hang your wind chime.

steps.title: Paint a small terracotta pot with acrylic paint, and let it dry.
steps.content: Paint a small terracotta pot with acrylic paint, and let it dry. [9] X Research source Once it dries, you can move on to the next step, or you can add more designs. You can also seal it with acrylic sealer if you'd like to make it last longer.

steps.title: Cut your string a little longer than you want it to be.
steps.content: Cut your string a little longer than you want it to be. You can use just about any type of string you want. Yarn, fishing line, and twine will all work wellâ€”it just needs to be thin enough to fit through your beads. You can cut as many strings as you want.

steps.title: Tie a bead, bell, or other charm onto the end of each string.
steps.content: Tie a bead, bell, or other charm onto the end of each string. Not only will this keep the rest of the beads from sliding off, but it will also add some weight and design to your chimes.

steps.title: Thread the beads onto each string, leaving a few inches blank.
steps.content: Thread the beads onto each string, leaving a few inches blank. You can follow a specific pattern, or you can string the beads randomly. You can use the same type of bead, or you can mix-and-match glass, plastic, wood, or metal beads.

steps.title: Hot glue the strings to the inside rim of your pot.
steps.content: Hot glue the strings to the inside rim of your pot. For extra support, tie a knot at the end of each string first, just above the last bead. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Cut a long piece of thick cord, fold it in half, and feed the loose ends through the hole at the top of your wind chime.
steps.content: Cut a long piece of thick cord, fold it in half, and feed the loose ends through the hole at the top of your wind chime. [11] X Research source You will be using this cord to hang up your wind chime, so make sure that it is sturdy. Slip the loose ends of the cord down through the hole and into the pot.

steps.title: Tie the ends into a thick knot to keep the loop from falling out.
steps.content: Tie the ends into a thick knot to keep the loop from falling out. If you need to, hot glue the knot to the inside of the pot. When you are done, use the loop to hang up your wind chime. If the cord still falls through the hole: slip the cord through the pot, then through a washer, then tie the cord into a knot.
